Legal_Issue: Whether Bloxom met the residency requirement under the Citizenship Act for Canadian citizenship
Application_Facts: Bloxom spent only 421 days in Canada during the relevant four-year period
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the citizenship judge's decision
Court_Ruling: Federal Court dismissed the application for judicial review
Defendant_Behavior: Failed to meet statutory physical presence requirement
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient physical presence in Canada as required by law
Legal_Standard: Minimum 1095 days of physical presence in Canada over four years
Assessment_Factor: Duration and pattern of physical presence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review following administrative denial of citizenship application
Review_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Record of days physically present in Canada
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section of the Citizenship Act regarding residency requirement
Application_Basis: Accumulation of physical presence days in Canada
Evidence_Assessed: Documented days of residency in Canada
Governing_Rule: Applicants must have at least 1095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Only 421 days of residency documented, falling short of 1095-day requirement
Decisional_Body: Citizenship judge; reviewed by Federal Court
Cause_Description: Bloxom's application was denied due to insufficient residency days
Evidence_Handling: Residency records were examined to calculate physical presence
Evidence_Issues: No dispute over accuracy of days recorded, but failure to meet threshold
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with minimum physical presence requirement
Legal_Provision: Citizenship Act – Residency requirement (1095 days in four years)
Evidence_Assessment: Objective calculation of days spent in Canada
Decision_Rationale: Statutory requirement not met; absences' rationale deemed irrelevant
Evidentiary_Issues: None raised; factual basis accepted but insufficient under law
